section1.title: What is Securities Fraud?
section1.p1: Securities fraud, also known as stock fraud or investment fraud, is a deceptive practice in the stock or commodities markets that induces investors to make purchase or sale decisions based on false information. It's a serious crime that can have devastating consequences for investors and the integrity of the financial markets.
section1.p2: In recent years, with the rise of social media and digital platforms, fraudsters have found new and innovative ways to target unsuspecting investors in India. According to SEBI data, the number of complaints related to stock market fraud has been on the rise, with thousands of crores lost by retail investors each year.
section1.p3: Common channels used by fraudsters include:
list: WhatsApp and Telegram groups offering "guaranteed returns".
Fake investment advisory websites and social media profiles.
Sophisticated Ponzi and pyramid schemes disguised as legitimate investments.
Pump and dump operations coordinated through online forums.

section2.title: Common Types of Stock Market Frauds

ponzi.title: Ponzi Schemes
ponzi.description: Fraudulent investing scams promising high rates of return with little risk to investors. They rely on a constant flow of new investment to pay returns to earlier investors.

pump_dump.title: Pump & Dump
pump_dump.description: Artificially inflating stock prices through false promotions, then selling at peak, leaving other investors with losses.

insider_trading.title: Insider Trading
insider_trading.description: Trading based on material, non-public information about a company, giving an unfair advantage.

fake_advisors.title: Fake Advisors
fake_advisors.description: Unregistered individuals or firms offering "guaranteed returns" and stock tips, often disappearing after receiving payment.

circular_trading.title: Circular Trading
circular_trading.description: A group of traders creating artificial trading volume by buying and selling securities among themselves, luring other investors.

front_running.title: Front Running
front_running.description: Brokers using advance knowledge of large client orders to make personal gains.

section3.title: SEBI's Role in Investor Protection
section3.p1: The Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is the primary regulatory body for the securities market in India. Its mission is to protect the interests of investors and to promote the development of, and to regulate, the securities market.
list: Registering and regulating all market intermediaries, such as brokers, investment advisers, and mutual funds.
Prohibiting fraudulent and unfair trade practices.
Investigating cases of market manipulation and insider trading.
Issuing guidelines and regulations to ensure market integrity.
